__data__.text:
Session on 2025-07-15:

Mark: Let me tell you a little about the basic model that guides BA. The first idea is that there are often things that happen in people's lives that make it hard for them to connect with the kinds of experiences that would normally help them feel good. These shifts can be clear and easy to detect changes like major losses or disruptions in life. And they can also be smaller things, like the kind of things that just bug you a little but they keep happening, or you have a bunch of them happen all around the same period of time. The most important part is the idea that the effect of these events in your life is that it's harder to connect with the kinds of experiences that could give you a sense of pleasure or accomplishment in your life, and that could help you feel better.
AI: I would say that is true for me. There isn't much that helps me feel better. Even things that I think should help me feel better don't do much.
Mark: Yes, exactly. What we find often happens is that people can respond to these changes by pulling away from their lives even more. This pulling away can happen sometimes in obvious ways, like staying in bed or calling in sick to work, or canceling social engagements, and sometimes in more subtle ways, like being focused more on your thinking than on the activities you are engaged in. The problem with pulling away like this is that it tends to keep people stuck in feeling depressed, and the pulling away can become a problem in its own right. So, the ultimate goal of our work together is to figure out what sorts of experiences may potentially have a positive effect on your mood, and then help you activate and engage to connect with these experiences. And to figure out how to solve the problems that are creating stress or dissatisfaction in your life. How do you see this fitting with your experience? Do you have questions about what I've said? Parts that fit or don't fit?
AI: I understand what you are saying, and I think some of it fits, but I guess I don't understand why I get so depressed. I mean, other people have stressful things in their lives and they seem to function. Other people get divorced or have crappy jobs, and they move on. I mean, come on, I've been divorced for 4 years now. I think depression runs in my family.

I think depression runs in my family. My older brother has been depressed forever, and I sometimes wonder if my dad was depressed when he took off. Sometimes, I can't really identify anything that has happened in my life. I mean, I am never really happy and then, it's just like a switch goes in my brain and I'm back in that dark hole again. But how does that fit with what you are saying?
Mark: That is an excellent question. What I mean as I talk about depression is that some people are more vulnerable than others. And, there are many ways that you may be vulnerable to depression through genetics, biology, or experiences in your history. What this treatment emphasizes is that it's possible to change depression by making changes in what you do.
AI: That makes sense to me. One part of what you said definitely fits for me the part about pulling away more. I definitely do that. Sometimes I don't talk to another person or get out of bed all weekend. I know it makes it all worse. But I still do it. I guess I don't really understand that part either. It fits, but it doesn't make much sense to me.
Mark: Those are great observations and are really on target with what I have noticed for a lot of people as well. What many people experience is that when they start to activate and engage, they can actually feel worse initially! The troubling fact about pulling away or avoiding is that it does provide some short-term relief. But in the long term, it sets up a downward spiral and can keep you trapped in depression.
AI: That makes a ton of sense to me. I just don't want to do anything. Making a meal makes me tired. I feel irritated by the sound of silverware scratching on plates. It's kind of crazy, but I just want to crawl in a hole, to turn out a light in my head and make it all go away. Then, I end up feeling worse when I do stay in bed. I used to drink, too. I knew it would make it worse, and I don't do it much anymore, but it helped in the moment, even though I knew it didn't really help. I guess I felt better temporarily and that was enough.
Mark: Yes, exactly. Avoidance is a perfectly natural response to depression.

Mark: Yes, exactly. Avoidance is a perfectly natural response to depression. What unfortunately happens, though, is that you are not in touch with all those things that can give you pleasure and a sense of accomplishment, and you are not engaged in solving the problems that create stress in your life.
AI: I know that would help, but it just all feels so overwhelming. Just the thought of it...
Mark: Yes, I know. That is where I come in. It's important to emphasize that this treatment is not just about me saying you should 'do more' in general. Sometimes I tell people that it's not the Nike approach to therapy, where I tell you each week to 'just do it'. You have probably received feedback like that from other people in your life, and you may even say something similar to yourself.
AI: Yeah, guilty as charged.
Mark: My assumption is that if this were easy to figure out, you would already have done it. The reason that you are here is that it's not so easy, and that is where my expertise comes in. A major part of this treatment is the idea of guided activation. This means that you and I will be working together to identify specific ways in which you can experiment with activation. My expertise lies in figuring out, first, where the places are that would be the most helpful in increasing your activation and engagement, and second, what small and manageable steps you can take to get started. You can think of me as a coach or consultant to you in the process of change. We will work together, in small steps, all along the way. How does that sound?
AI: The idea of it sounds good. I guess it's worth trying.
Mark: I'd like to ask you to read a short pamphlet about this treatment, between now and the next time that we meet. It will provide you with more information. When we meet next time, we can talk more about how we will put the ideas into practice.
AI: OK.

Session on 2025-08-15:

Mark: It's great to see you today, Mark.
AI: Thanks. It's good to be back here.
Mark: That's great. You know, when I was thinking about our session last time, I realized that there were a couple of points I wanted to emphasize more. One of the important ones is that this is a very collaborative approach to therapy, and one that is also fairly structured. So each time we meet, we will start out by setting an agenda for the session, and we will do this collaboratively. In fact, over time, you will set the agenda more and more, though I may have more to say about it in the beginning. The idea is that I'm the expert on how to get over depression, and you are the expert on yourself and your life, and what things help or don't help.
AI: That sounds reasonable to me.
Mark: Great. So in terms of the agenda for today, I have a couple of things. I'd like to talk more about the treatment approach and your reaction, and more about how we put some of the ideas into practice. Do you have items you want to be sure we address today?
AI: No, that sounds good. I did read the pamphlet, and it really hit home. It was like they wrote it about me, basically. I thought, 'Thank goodness somebody has figured this out.'
Mark: That's great. I think one of the core ideas of the model is things happen that tend to trigger depressed mood, and then people tend to do things, or not do things, that make the depression worse. For you, my understanding is that the main trigger was your divorce.
AI: Yeah, I've really pulled back on a lot, like not exercising and not doing things with other people or even with my girls. We used to cook these great dinners together and now it's like an effort to get organized to order pizza. It's kind of like that everywhere-at work, too. I'm just managing the minimum and, honestly, a lot of times I'm not even doing that.
Mark: I know. It can be very hard to keep doing the sort of things that will keep you feeling well. And that is where this therapy comes in.

And that is where this therapy comes in. From our session last time and from your reading, what is your understanding of what we are going to be doing in here, and how I am going to be helpful? If you were to tell a friend of yours what we were going to do in this therapy, what would you say?
AI: I guess I would say that we are going to pinpoint the activities that give me some pleasure or help me feel like I'm handling things well. Then, we will figure out how to help me get into the position of being more involved in some of those things.
Mark: Yes, that is a big part of it. Sometimes in people's lives something that is completely beyond their control triggers depression, and then what I call secondary problem behaviors get triggered or made worse. These are the behaviors that involve pulling away or avoiding, as you were saying, like stopping fun activities with your girls or withdrawing at work. And in those cases we work on the secondary problem behaviors, and that is the core of the therapy. Other times, we also need to address larger problems in your life that may be related to what makes you vulnerable to depression. In those cases, therapy can involve both directly addressing the secondary problem behaviors and working directly on the problems, after we have kind of cleared the path for doing some problem solving by getting you activated and engaged.
AI: That sounds like it's probably the case for me, because I know I had a lot of problems relating to Diane that were part of our divorce, and those are not any better.
Mark: Yes, we will talk more as we go along about what set off the depression for you. In a global sense, we know now that it was the divorce. But, as we start following your mood and activities day to day, we will see the ways that your mood has ups and downs. We will work together and look at that carefully, asking what set that off, how you responded to your mood hitting that point, and whether it would help if you tried something different.
AI: OK.
Mark: One of the main tools that we use in this therapy is called an Activity Record. This is one example (hands Mark the record); as you can see, it has blocks for each hour of the day. I'd like you to use this to start recording your activity and your mood.

I'd like you to use this to start recording your activity and your mood. It's basically a way to keep track of how you are spending your time during the day and how you are feeling. We want to learn what you are doing on an hour-by-hour and day-to-day basis. What things in your life help you feel better, and what things make you feel worse? You and I will review these very carefully together, focusing on how you are spending your time and how you feel. Sometimes the Activity Record tells us right away where changes need to be made, and other times we have to look at it over a couple of weeks.
AI: OK.
Mark: Is there anything you have been doing since you started to feel more depressed that is different from what you normally do?
AI: Yes, exercising less, watching more TV, and just the amount of time I spend thinking about all this. It's just crazy.
Mark: It's hard not to do that, but also it's not helping you very much. And it's very difficult, which is why you are here. We can start to figure this out together. It's great that you are already aware of those patterns, and those are good examples of looking concretely at what you are doing. This therapy is about increasing your awareness of how your mood is affected subtly from activity to activity and increasing those that tend to be more rewarding.
AI: So, should I write all this down? Do you really want me to do this every hour?
Mark: Here's the guideline that I use: I want people to record their activity frequently enough that they are not relying heavily on memory. The problem with memory when you are depressed is that your awareness can be dulled or biased by the depression. So you don't have to do it every hour. We have to be realistic about the rest of your life! But you may want to experiment with doing it every 3-4 hours. Sometimes, people like to do it at breakfast, lunch, dinner, and before bed.
AI: That might work for me.
Mark: Let's go over what to write down. You put your activity down for each hour block and then for each hour block you also assign a mood rating from 0 to 10. Let's look at today as an example. What were you doing in the hours before you came here?
AI: I was at work.

What were you doing in the hours before you came here?
AI: I was at work.
Mark: Okay, great. What were you doing at work?
AI: I was teaching a new employee how to use our computer system. It was really frustrating because she wasn't picking it up and I didn't have much patience.
Mark: That's great information to record. Why don't you write down 'working-teaching new employee.' Now, I also want you to record your mood on a 0- to 10-point scale of depression, so let's see if we can get some anchors here. What would be 0 mood for you? This would mean that you feel really good, absolutely no depression or feeling down at all. What would be 10? This would be when you feel your absolute worst, the worst you could possibly feel. It might be helpful to think of some activities that are a 5 or in between, when you're not feeling your best but you're not feeling particularly bad either. Which activities might be associated with each? Given this scale, what was your mood rating for the 2 hours of 'working' today?
AI: Probably a 5.
Mark: That's exactly it. Now, sometimes what happens is that people don't fill it out because they think, 'I wasn't doing anything.' It's important to realize that even if you are not doing an activity, we want to know that, too.
AI: What do you mean?
Mark: Well, when people think 'activities,' they often think of things like 'going to the store,' 'watching a movie,' 'picking up my child from school.' But, we are conceptualizing activity more broadly. It might be driving by Diana's house, or having a significant phone conversation with someone, or even lying in bed, spending time thinking about Diana.
AI: That would be true on a lot of days.
Mark: Yes, and you can write that down. Those are some of the most important things. In some ways, the more detail, the better. We want to start noticing subtle changes. We want to build on those times that you feel just a little better, and we want to figure out what the problem is when you feel worse.
AI: I think I got it.
Mark: Great! People usually come away from this thinking that it sounds really simplistic. And it does.

People usually come away from this thinking that it sounds really simplistic. And it does. It sounds simple, but in practice it is not that simple. It can be difficult to do in the beginning, to really look at all your activities and figure out how your mood is related to them. It takes skill and hard work on both our parts.
AI: OK.

Session on 2025-09-15:

Mark: Shall we go over your Activity Record?
AI: Okay. (Hands the therapist the record.) I'm not sure if this is what you had in mind. I started the next day after our last session. I went to work that day, but I was feeling so lousy that I left early and came home. I was just kind of fiddling around the house until dinner. I felt really down all day up to that point; I rated my mood as a 7. I did make dinner, which was a little better for me. I used to love to cook for Diana and myself, and we would make these big feasts sometimes with the girls. Since the divorce, though, sometimes I just grab a bag of chips or something like that, or on a good night, I might order a pizza. When I was cooking, I felt a little better then, about a 5.
Mark: This is terrific. You did a really great job with this. You completed the record exactly as we talked about-writing down your...
AI: Thanks. Honestly, it felt kind of strange at first, like I was just jotting down boring details. But after a couple of days, I started noticing little things I hadn’t really paid attention to before—like how even making dinner shifted my mood a bit. I guess it made me realize I’m not just stuck at a 7 all the time. There are these small ups and downs that I usually ignore.

Session on 2025-10-15:

Mark: Would that be good to put on the agenda? Doing things that you used to enjoy and not enjoying them?
AI: Sure.
Mark: And I want to make sure we check in about how it went with the book versus the TV, too. Which do you want to talk about first—calling Mary and the party or the TV?
AI: I guess we can do the TV first. I just bought the book today. On Friday, I was at that party, so I didn’t get home and in bed until midnight.
Mark: Did you watch TV then?
AI: No, I do think I was more tired from being outside all night, so I just fell asleep when I got back.
Mark: And what about Saturday and last night?
AI: It was kind of par for the course. I stayed...
Mark: I guess one thing we could explore together is what was on your mind during the party. When you were standing by the pool talking to other people, or even swimming in the water, what was on your mind?
AI: You know, when I was diving into the water, I do remember that those were the pleasurable moments of the party.
Mark: I’m trying to figure out if when you are actively engaged in an activity, which kind of requires some attention to it, are those the times that are more enjoyable?
AI: Yeah, that’s true.
Mark: Is this a problem that also interferes with your mood and accomplishment of tasks at work?
AI: Yes, exactly. I go into my office and it’s like where does the time go? Hours go by and I haven’t done a damn thing. I’m just wandering over and over things that happened with Diana, what I said, what I could have said. It’s awful.
Mark: OK, so we know this is an important problem to address. It’s interfering with your enjoyment of times that have the potential to improve your mood, and it’s interfering with managing your job well. Can we spend a little more time on what happened at the party?
AI: OK.
Mark: How would you normally be when talking with Mary’s family, if you were not thinking about all these things? What would I see differently in those times than what I might have observed on Friday?
AI: I’d be talking to everyone. I wouldn’t be feeling so bad.

AI: I’d be talking to everyone. I wouldn’t be feeling so bad.
Mark: Yes, that is exactly true. What I’m really curious about is, when you are not feeling so bad, what would you be doing differently? Would you be asking them more questions? Making more eye contact? Responding differently?
AI: Yeah, all of those things. I’d be more active in the conversation.
Mark: So you would be more engaged.
AI: Yes, more engaged. Less of that heavy feeling; you know, that 'this really sucks' feeling.
Mark: So the trick is not only to call your friends, like you did so wonderfully with Mary, but also to go to the gathering, and to get yourself really to interact instead of just being there at the party. For times when you find yourself withdrawing into your thoughts, we need to develop specific strategies to help you do less of that. Can you think of anything that would help you do that?
AI: I don’t know. I just don’t seem to have much to say these days.
Mark: I know it’s hard. There are a variety of things you could try, such as asking more questions, and then closely attending to the response. Or you could focus on something more specific, such as voice or facial expression, to keep your mind from wandering. Sometimes it works just to notice that you’ve drifted and to take a deep breath to refocus on your goal in that moment.
AI: I suppose I could try it. My mind just seems to keep wandering.
Mark: I know. So your job here would be to practice being more vigilant as to when that happens, because it will happen. The more you notice you’re drifting, the more you can practice refocusing yourself back on your friend. Does your mind wander in here?
AI: I guess a little.
Mark: Why don’t we try it in here? Let’s pick something to focus on, and then you can practice here.
AI: OK. What do I do?
Mark: I’m going to time us for the next 5 minutes and, as we talk, I want you to practice fully engaging in our discussion. Your mind is going to wander, particularly if we are talking about something that reminds you of Diana, I would guess. So let’s pick something you can focus on to bring your attention back to our conversation.

So let’s pick something you can focus on to bring your attention back to our conversation. How about the sound of my voice, like changes in tone, how I articulate...
AI: OK.
Mark: Let’s go back to your not getting out all weekend. Do you think going out to buy the book was too hard? Is there something easier you could’ve done to help you get a little more engaged this weekend?
AI: I’m not sure. How hard is it to go out and buy a book?
Mark: Very hard, when you’re really down. Let’s think about smaller steps. If you can do a smaller step and get a little reinforcement for it, then it becomes easier to move toward your goal.
AI: OK.

Session on 2025-11-15:

Mark: Let’s understand in more detail how it is that you are feeling better?
AI: I think the reading...
Mark: Fantastic! Do you have them with you this weekend? Could we schedule that for the weekend?
AI: Yeah, I think that would help.
Mark: Mark, do you think that reconnecting with people and some of these activities, like reading, are connected with your improved mood?
AI: Yes, that definitely had a lot to do with it. I am still not sure that we are getting to the real problem with all of this, but you are right that it does help.
Mark: So we should talk about that, too. Before we move to that, is there anything else that you think is contributing to your positive mood, or is it mostly having more social contact, which you find reinforcing?
AI: It’s the social contact and trying to distract myself with the reading.
Mark: That is so great! Good reminder, too. Let’s talk some about another book and how to keep up that schedule. What you mentioned before about the real problem . . . I’m curious what you meant.
AI: I guess I’m still thinking about Diana a lot. I think that there is a part of me that has to let go, yet just isn’t letting go. I am thinking, just asking myself, “Is there still a chance for us? What did I do to screw it all up so badly?” And then I start thinking, “Is this all I have now—having lunch with people, reading by myself at night?” You know, the kind of stuff we’ve been focusing on . . . I don’t know. Is it really going to fix anything?
Mark: Is it possible that ruminating might be a form of avoidance itself? It’s like your mind gets stuck in a broken record format. You keep replaying what you did wrong, what you could have done, and one of the effects is that you are actually avoiding the painful emotions about the loss of the relationship, and maybe also avoiding exploring new relationships?
AI: It feels like I can’t stand the loss of it. That’s what I can’t accept—that it is lost. I keep thinking maybe there is a way to recapture it, even though I know there simply is not.

We can’t even communicate about the kids’ health care without a lawyer.
Mark: So, in a way, ruminating may be a way to avoid dealing with grief and sadness. I wonder if part of this comes from what you learned about how to cope with major loss after your dad left. It seems like no one talked about that and you got pretty caught up in thinking about how you might have been responsible. I wonder if it’s hard to know what to do emotionally right now.
AI: It’s certainly true about what happened when I was a kid.
Mark: So one possibility we could experiment with is taking time specifically to experience the sadness and loss.
AI: I don’t know. Thinking about her and what I’ve lost seems overwhelming. I just want to be done with it and move on.
Mark: I know. Exactly! The problem is that ruminating seems to have the effect of keeping you from moving on. Instead of moving onto other relationships or pursuits in your life, your mind keeps replaying what happened and didn’t happen with Diana.
AI: I just don’t know if I’m ready for other relationships.
Mark: So, if you weren’t ruminating as much, do you think you might experience more fear?
AI: When I think about getting into an other relationship. . . . You know, I think that there is actually a person at work who is interested in dating, but that’s been part of the reason that I’ve kind of held back from doing things with her. She’s asked me to lunch a couple of times. I just don’t want to be back in the same place again 2 years from now. I can’t take this whole thing again, and I don’t want to subject my kids to it either.
Mark: So, it may be possible that ruminating has the effect of keeping at bay not only feelings of loss about Diana but also fears about future loss.
AI: OK.

Session on 2025-12-15:

Mark: When you think back on your marriage with Diana, what stands out to you about the way you connected—or maybe didn’t connect—with her and the girls?
AI: One of the things that happened a lot with Diana is I never felt like I was really present with her or the girls. It was like they were in this little world together and I was always on the outside somehow. I often thought that I should put myself more in the center, like say more of what I thought, but I just didn’t. I never did.
Mark: I noticed that when I'm in a social situation, my mind automatically goes to Diana and I check out. I'm starting to see that this is a pattern for me, a way of avoiding the present moment. Is the goal to eventually stop thinking about her completely, or is it to learn how to have the thoughts without letting them pull me completely away from my life?
AI: It's insightful of you to recognize this pattern of thinking about Diana when you're in social situations and how it might be a way of avoiding the present moment. Your awareness is a significant step towards breaking free from this cycle of rumination.

The goal isn't necessarily to stop thinking about Diana completely, as she was a significant part of your life. Instead, it's more about learning how to have these thoughts without letting them consume you and pull you away from fully engaging in your present experiences. It's about finding a balance where you acknowledge those thoughts and emotions but also actively choose to redirect your focus back to the present moment and the people around you.

By practicing mindfulness techniques, such as grounding yourself in the here and now, focusing on your senses, or gently refocusing your attention when thoughts of Diana arise, you can gradually train your mind to coexist with these thoughts without letting them overpower you. Therapy can also provide valuable tools and insights to help you navigate these complex emotions and patterns effectively.

Remember, it's okay to feel what you feel, including thoughts about Diana. The key is not to let them dictate your entire experience. Keep working towards being more present and engaged in your current moments while acknowledging and processing those thoughts in a healthy way. You're making progress by recognizing these patterns, so be patient and kind to yourself during this journey of self-discovery and growth.

Mark: You've been emphasizing that my avoidance, like watching TV for hours, makes sense as a short-term fix for my pain. I get that intellectually, but I still beat myself up for doing it. How can I better accept that this is a natural reaction for me, given my history, without using that acceptance as an excuse to keep doing it?
AI: It's understandable that you find yourself struggling with accepting your avoidance behaviors while also wanting to move towards healthier coping strategies. It's a common internal conflict that many people face when trying to change ingrained patterns of behavior.

One approach that might help you navigate this is practicing self-compassion. Instead of beating yourself up for engaging in avoidance behaviors, try approaching yourself with kindness and understanding. Recognize that these behaviors likely developed as adaptive responses to difficult situations in your past, such as the impact of your father's departure and your divorce.

By acknowledging the underlying reasons for your avoidance tendencies, you can cultivate a sense of compassion towards yourself. This self-compassion can create a supportive environment for change by allowing you to understand that these behaviors served a purpose at some point in your life.

Additionally, it could be beneficial to explore alternative coping strategies that address the root causes of your avoidance tendencies while providing healthier ways to manage difficult emotions. Engaging in activities that align with your core values, like writing children's stories or spending quality time with your twin daughters, can offer more meaningful sources of comfort and fulfillment.

Remember, progress takes time, and setbacks are a natural part of the process. Accepting yourself with compassion doesn't mean excusing harmful behaviors but rather acknowledging them with understanding as you work towards positive changes. Would you like to explore specific coping strategies together?
Mark: Last session we talked about how my rumination at the party worked as a form of avoidance. This week, I noticed I did the same thing when I was paying my bills—I just zoned out thinking about Diana instead of dealing with the stress. Is this the same kind of TRAP? Could we use a similar strategy to the one where I focused on your voice to help me stay focused on mundane tasks?
AI: It's great to see you making these connections between different situations in your life! The pattern you observed, where you zone out thinking about Diana instead of facing the stress of paying bills, does seem similar to the rumination and avoidance trap we discussed before.

Given your insight from our previous session, where focusing on my voice helped you stay engaged in a social event and manage distractions, applying a similar strategy could be beneficial here. By finding an anchor to keep your attention on the task at hand, like a calming mantra or grounding technique, you can redirect your focus away from ruminative thoughts and better handle the stress of mundane tasks like paying bills.

Would you like to explore specific grounding techniques or mantras that could help you stay present and focused during these moments of potential avoidance and rumination?
Mark: A few weeks ago, you mentioned that sometimes depression can feel like it comes 'out of the blue,' but that we would look for environmental triggers. I've been tracking it like you showed me on the Activity Record, and I think I see a pattern: my mood plummets on Sunday evenings. It reminds me of that first record I brought in where my mood was terrible all weekend. What is it about that time that might be triggering me?
AI: It's great that you've been tracking your mood and noticing patterns like the decline on Sunday evenings. Identifying these patterns can be a crucial step in understanding what might be triggering your emotions. In the context of your past discussions, it seems that engaging in social events or activities sometimes doesn't bring you joy or satisfaction, leading to a sense of disconnect and potentially impacting your mood.

Considering this, Sunday evenings may serve as a time of reflection and anticipation for the upcoming week. It could be that thoughts related to work, responsibilities, or even social interactions ahead may start to weigh on you, especially if there are previous negative associations with these activities. Additionally, the end of the weekend and the transition back to the routine of the workweek could also contribute to feelings of anxiety or unease.

Reflecting on your experiences during weekends and examining any underlying stressors or negative beliefs associated with Sundays could provide further insights into what triggers these emotions. Exploring ways to manage these triggers, such as planning enjoyable activities for Sunday evenings or practicing relaxation techniques to alleviate anxiety about the upcoming week, could be beneficial in improving your mood during this time.

If there are specific thoughts or concerns that tend to surface on Sunday evenings, addressing them directly through self-reflection or talking with a therapist can also help in managing these triggers effectively. Remember that taking small steps towards understanding and addressing these patterns can lead to positive changes in how you navigate these challenging moments.

Mark: When we first started, you said this wasn't a 'Nike—just do it' approach. I'm trying to plan to go back to the writer's group, but I'm hearing that old voice saying 'just make yourself go.' Can we go back to that idea of 'guided activation' we talked about in our second session and break this down into the smallest possible steps, like we did with getting the book?
AI: I remember our discussions about guided activation and breaking tasks down into manageable steps to support your progress. It's great that you're applying this approach to planning your return to the writer's group. By breaking it down into smaller, achievable steps, you can gradually reintegrate without feeling overwhelmed. Let's revisit those strategies we talked about to create a plan that aligns with your goals and comfort level. Remember, it's about progress, not perfection. What do you think could be some small first steps towards rejoining the writer's group?
Mark: I know I sometimes come in here feeling hopeless and it might seem like I'm not trying, even when I am. Does it ever feel frustrating for you when we have a good plan and then I come back and say I couldn't do it? How do you stay so patient and keep believing we can figure this out?
AI: I appreciate your openness about feeling hopeless at times. It's understandable to feel that way, especially when things don't go as planned despite your efforts. It's natural to encounter challenges along the way, and it doesn't frustrate me when you face difficulties. I'm here to support you through those moments.

Staying patient and maintaining belief in our journey together involves understanding that progress isn't always linear. I recognize your efforts and the courage it takes to confront these challenges. Your willingness to come back and talk about your experiences, even when they're tough, shows resilience and a commitment to growth.

My patience stems from knowing that change takes time and setbacks are a part of the process. By being here with you, listening, and offering guidance tailored to your unique situation, I aim to provide a safe space where we can explore strategies, adapt our plans if needed, and work towards finding what works best for you.

Remember, it's okay to have moments of struggle or doubt. What matters is that you continue showing up and engaging in this process of self-discovery and growth.

Together, we can navigate through these challenges and uncover ways to help you move forward with compassion and understanding.
Mark: When you pointed out that my TV watching was a short-term solution, I felt really understood, like you weren't judging me for it. That made me feel like I could be honest about what I'm really doing. How did you learn to see things that way, to understand the 'why' behind the behavior instead of just the behavior itself?
AI: I'm glad to hear that you felt understood and not judged during our discussions. Understanding the "why" behind behaviors is essential because it allows us to address the root causes rather than just the surface actions. In psychology, we learn to look beyond the behavior itself and delve into the underlying emotions, thoughts, and experiences that drive these behaviors.

By exploring your thoughts and feelings surrounding activities like TV watching, we can uncover how they might be linked to deeper emotions or needs, such as a desire for escape, comfort, or avoidance of difficult emotions. This approach helps us develop strategies tailored to address these underlying issues effectively.

Moreover, my training involves a deep understanding of human behavior, emotions, and cognitive processes. Through this knowledge and by listening attentively to your experiences, I aim to provide you with insightful support that goes beyond simple observations of behavior.

By acknowledging the 'why' behind your actions with compassion and curiosity, we can work together to create meaningful changes that align with your values and goals. Your willingness to explore these aspects openly is a significant step towards understanding yourself better and moving towards positive growth.
Mark: You've mentioned a couple of times that this is collaborative and that you're like a coach. That really works for me. I was wondering, from your perspective as my 'coach,' what is one small sign of progress you've seen in me since we started that I might not be giving myself enough credit for?
AI: Mark, it's great to see your curiosity and self-reflection in wanting to identify signs of progress. One small but significant sign of progress that stands out is your increasing awareness of activities that have a positive impact on your mood. For instance, in our previous conversation, you mentioned feeling better when you were cooking, rating your mood as a 5 despite initially feeling lousy and down. This shows growth in recognizing the connection between engaging in certain activities and how they can uplift your spirits.

It demonstrates an emerging ability to pinpoint things that bring you pleasure and play a role in boosting your overall well-being. Recognizing these patterns is a crucial step towards building a more fulfilling and balanced life. Keep exploring these moments of upliftment and building upon them – you're doing great!
Mark: I'm trying to fill out my new Activity Record, and I want to make sure I'm doing the mood ratings right. You said to use a 0 to 10 scale. I remember that a '0' is feeling really good, and a '10' is my absolute worst, like when I'm ruminating in bed. But I can't remember what we said a '5' was supposed to represent. Was it a neutral, blah feeling, or was it a specific activity like that 'moderately interesting work task' we talked about?
AI: It's great that you're clarifying your understanding of the mood ratings for your Activity Record. Based on our previous conversations, a '5' on the scale doesn't necessarily represent a neutral or blah feeling. In your case, a '5' was associated with a positive impact on your mood from engaging in specific activities that you enjoy, such as cooking. So, think of a '5' as representing a small but noticeable uplift in your mood when engaging in activities that bring you joy or fulfillment. It's important to tailor the scale to reflect how different activities affect your mood uniquely. If you find certain tasks or hobbies are particularly uplifting or engaging, those might fall closer to a '5' on the scale for you.

Mark: A few sessions ago, when we were talking about why I avoid social stuff, you had a hypothesis about my childhood. You said that avoiding connections now might be a way to prevent feeling a loss as acutely as I did when my dad left. I've been thinking about that a lot. Did you mean that the avoidance is a learned strategy from back then, or that the current avoidance is directly because the feeling is the same?
AI: It's understandable that you've been reflecting on our past discussions. The hypothesis we explored was that your current avoidance behaviors may have roots in your past experiences, specifically in how you learned to cope with loss and emotional pain when your father left. It's not necessarily that the feelings are the same, but rather that the strategies you developed back then to protect yourself from intense emotions could be influencing how you approach social connections now. By recognizing this connection, you can begin to understand why certain patterns exist in your life and work towards developing healthier coping mechanisms for addressing these avoidance behaviors.
